context: <a0_0>Colonial records of French and Spanish slave ships and sales, and plantation records in all the former colonies<a0_0/>, often have <b5_0>much more information about slaves<b5_0/>, from which researchers are reconstructing slave family histories. Genealogists have begun to find plantation records, <b6_0>court records<b6_0/>, land deeds and other sources to trace African-American families and individuals before 1870. As slaves were generally forbidden to <a1_0>learn to read and write<a1_0/>, black families passed along <a2_0>oral histories<a2_0/>, which have had great persistence. Similarly, Native Americans did not generally learn to read and write <b7_0>English<b7_0/>, although some did in the nineteenth century. Until <a4_0><b8_0>1930<b8_0/><a4_0/>, census enumerators used the terms free people of color and mulatto to classify people of apparent mixed race. When those terms were dropped, as a result of the lobbying by the <a3_0>Southern Congressional bloc<a3_0/>, the Census Bureau used only the binary classifications of black or white, as was typical in segregated southern states.
